thread.title: Theresa May insists she can still sign a Brexit deal despite failure of talks

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Theresa May insists she can still sign a Brexit deal despite failure of talks
text:
Theresa May insists she can still sign a Brexit deal despite failure of talks Critics say Nissan's decision to delay pay talks is a symptom of Brexit uncertainty Share The People's Vote March and Rally takes place in Sunderland City Centre led by Conservative MP Anna Soubry and Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Prime Minister Theresa May has insisted that a Brexit deal is still “achievable” - despite talks breaking down just days ahead of a crunch European Council summit.
Mrs May called for “cool, calm heads to prevail” after talks last weekend failed to bridge differences between the UK and EU over the future status of the border in Ireland.
But she was forced to defend her Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, following claims that he was undermining her.
Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell said there were reports that Mr Raab had promised Mrs May he would support her proposed EU deal, known as the Chequers deal, while also promising hardcore Brexiteer MPs that he would block it.
She said: “Will the Prime Minister confirm that this couldn’t possibly be the case and she has full confidence in the Secretary of State?”
The Prime Minister insisted: “Yes I do have absolute full confidence.” Read More Sexual harassment and bullying in the House of Commons revealed in shocking dossier
Mrs May was addressing the House of Commons just two days before she travels to Brussels for an EU summit.
It had been hoped that the EU and the UK would come to an agreement at the summit about future trade and security relations.
But talks stalled when Mr Raab met EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier on Sunday.
Mrs May has offered to keep the whole of the UK temporarily in a customs union with the EU until a broader trade deal is in place, avoiding the need for customs and regulatory checks at the Irish border.
But it also wants a mechanism to ensure the arrangement doesn’t become permanent - which the EU appears to object to.
The Prime Minister told MPs: “I continue to believe that a negotiated deal is the best outcome for the UK and for the European Union.
“I continue to believe that such a deal is achievable.”
Conservative opponents of Theresa May’s Chequers deal including Berwick-upon-Tweed MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan, a Parliamentary private secretary in the Department for Education. Conservative MP for Berwick Anne-Marie Trevelyan (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
Like many Tory rebels, including former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, she instead is calling on the UK to sign a deal with the EU similar to the one agreed between the EU and Canada.
She said in a column written for a newspaper: “Brexit gives us a rare, brief and historic opportunity to change our country’s future and for us to become, once again, a self-governing, free-trading nation. So the deal we strike with the EU must ensure that the UK’s regulations and trade relations become truly independent.
“I continue to be concerned that the Chequers proposal could not give us this regulatory freedom and trade independence.” Read More Treasury invites proposals for 'freeport' to create 25,000 North East jobs
But critics of Brexit said Nissan’s decision to delay pay talks showed that workers were suffering because of continued uncertainty.
Nissan, which operates Britain’s biggest car plant at Sunderland, announced it had delayed the start of pay talks with its staff until it has “better clarity on the future business outlook”.
Sunderland Central MP Julie Elliott said: “Once again the uncertainty surrounding the position we are in with the Brexit negotiations is having an impact on workers in the car industry and in the North East.
“An agreement needs to be reached as a matter of urgency so that businesses can plan for the future.
“The government are putting tens of thousands of jobs at risk with its chaotic approach to Brexit. They must do more to protect the rights and livelihoods of hard working people in the North East, and across the UK.” Read More
Supporters of a second referendum on Brexit, or so-called People’s Vote, are to march in London on Saturday, October 20, following the success of a march attended by more than 100,000 people in June.
Those attending include Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson, who said on Twitter: “I’ll be there”. Like us on Facebook
